<A NAME="A2224732Z20-F_HTM_PAGE_DK49901_1_39">
</A>
<UL>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	other key features of our products (including Flex functionality, RF-loopback, mesh nodes and tri-mode mesh panel
	features).
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
</UL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
	patent portfolio consists of 22&nbsp;issued U.S.&nbsp;patents, 2&nbsp;issued Canadian patents, 80&nbsp;issued European patents, 10&nbsp;pending European applications and
	24&nbsp;pending U.S.&nbsp;applications.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
	connection with the NSN Transaction, we use certain patents and other intellectual property rights owned by Nokia under license and in connection with the disposition of Axerra, we
	use certain patents and other intellectual property rights owned by the acquirers of Axerra under&nbsp;license.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
	executable code for our software and firmware, the embedded software and firmware in our hardware products and our manufacturing designs are protected under trade secret law and as
	unpublished, copyrighted works. Software is only provided to our customers in binary format, subject to industry standard source code escrow arrangements with key customers. We license the use of our
	product to our customers and resellers. These licenses contain standard provisions prohibiting the unauthorized reproduction, disclosure, reverse engineering or transfer of our product. In addition,
	we are designing product changes intended to enable the implementation of encrypted embedded firmware to further enhance our ability to protect our intellectual property. We recognize, however, that
	effective copyright protection may not be available in some countries in which we distribute products.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
	general practice is to enter into confidentiality and non-disclosure agreements with our employees, consultants, manufacturers, suppliers, customers, channel partners and others to
	attempt to limit access to and distribution of our proprietary information. In addition, our practice is to enter into agreements with our employees that include an assignment to us of all
	intellectual property developed by each of them in the course of their employment.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
	have registered trade-marks DRAGONWAVE, AIRPAIR and HORIZON in Canada and in the U.S.&nbsp;We have a registered trade-mark for DRAGONWAVE in China and have a pending trade-mark
	application in the European Union and India for DRAGONWAVE. We have a registered trade-mark for AVENUE in the U.S. and have a pending trade-mark application in India. In connection with the Renewed
	Framework, we have been granted an exclusive licence, without the right to grant sub-licences, to use the trade-marks HUB800 and FIRSTMILE200 and an exclusive license for certain field of use and a
	non-exclusive licence for certain other fields of use, without the right to grant sub-licences, to use the trade-marks LITE and&nbsp;NETVIEWER.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See
	"Part&nbsp;I&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;Item&nbsp;3.&nbsp;Key Information&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;D.&nbsp;Risk Factors" pertaining to
	intellectual property&nbsp;below.
</FONT>
</P>

<DIV STYLE="WIDTH:100%;BORDER:SOLID #000000 1PT;MARGIN-RIGHT:1PT;PADDING-TOP:1PT;PADDING-RIGHT:3PT;PADDING-BOTTOM:2PT;PADDING-LEFT:4PT;">
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;Cycles
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;">
</P>
</DIV>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;There
	is no seasonal effect on our sales patterns; however, quarterly results may fluctuate especially when multi-year or multi-quarter projects are booked. Cyclical effects related to
	our relationship with our principal channel partner, Nokia, have been observed in our fourth quarter as it overlaps with the beginning of Nokia's calendar fiscal&nbsp;year.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<!-- BOXING PARAGRAPH(S) -->
</FONT>
</P>
<DIV STYLE="WIDTH:100%;BORDER:SOLID #000000 1PT;MARGIN-RIGHT:1PT;PADDING-TOP:1PT;PADDING-RIGHT:3PT;PADDING-BOTTOM:2PT;PADDING-LEFT:4PT;">
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;Economic Dependence
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;">
</P>
</DIV>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Following
	the closing of the NSN Transaction, our economic dependence profile changed significantly. In the fiscal year ended February&nbsp;28, 2015, Nokia and one other key customer
	each contributed over 10% of our revenue. Specifically, revenue through the Nokia channel represented approximately 53% of our total revenue during the fiscal year ended February&nbsp;28, 2015. Our
	other key customer accounted for 16% of revenue in the fiscal year ended February&nbsp;28,&nbsp;2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
	supply products to our customers, including Nokia, on a purchase order basis and, accordingly, customers are generally under no ongoing obligation to buy our products. If one or more
	of our customers discontinues its relationship with us for any reason, or reduces or postpones current or expected purchases of our products or services, our business, results of operations and
	financial condition could be materially adversely affected.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	39
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>

<A NAME="A2224732Z20-F_HTM_PAGE_DK49901_1_40">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;While
	Nokia has reaffirmed its commitment to partnering, both Nokia's recent introduction of a multi-vendor microwave ecosystem and the proposed Alcatel-Lucent combination increases
	uncertainty for the future of the Nokia channel. See "Part&nbsp;I&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;Item&nbsp;4.&nbsp;Information on the
	Company&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;A.&nbsp;History&nbsp;&amp; Business Developments&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;Mergers&nbsp;&amp; Acquisitions and Joint
	Ventures&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;Acquisition of Microwave Transport Business of NSN and Relationship with Nokia",

</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<!-- BOXING PARAGRAPH(S) -->
</FONT>
</P>
<DIV STYLE="WIDTH:100%;BORDER:SOLID #000000 1PT;MARGIN-RIGHT:1PT;PADDING-TOP:1PT;PADDING-RIGHT:3PT;PADDING-BOTTOM:2PT;PADDING-LEFT:4PT;">
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>

	&nbsp;&nbsp;Changes to Contracts
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;">
</P>
</DIV>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
	discussed above under "Part&nbsp;I&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;Item&nbsp;4.&nbsp;Information on the
	Company&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;A.&nbsp;History&nbsp;&amp; Business Developments&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;Mergers&nbsp;&amp; Acquisitions and Joint
	Ventures&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;Acquisition of Microwave Transport Business of NSN and Relationship with Nokia", in light of recent developments within Nokia we are seeking Nokia's
	agreement to changes to our existing contractual framework to support our cash flows and rationalize future legacy support obligations.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<!-- BOXING PARAGRAPH(S) -->
</FONT>
</P>
<DIV STYLE="WIDTH:100%;BORDER:SOLID #000000 1PT;MARGIN-RIGHT:1PT;PADDING-TOP:1PT;PADDING-RIGHT:3PT;PADDING-BOTTOM:2PT;PADDING-LEFT:4PT;">
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;Environmental Protection
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;">
</P>
</DIV>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Environmental
	protection requirements currently have no material financial or operational effect on our capital expenditures, earnings or competitive position, and are not expected to
	have any material effect in future years. While we are currently unaware of any negative effects associated with our products, allegations of health and safety risks associated with wireless products
	have been publicized from time to time. See "Part&nbsp;I&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;Item&nbsp;3.&nbsp;Key
	Information&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;D.&nbsp;Risk&nbsp;Factors".
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<!-- BOXING PARAGRAPH(S) -->
</FONT>
</P>
<DIV STYLE="WIDTH:100%;BORDER:SOLID #000000 1PT;MARGIN-RIGHT:1PT;PADDING-TOP:1PT;PADDING-RIGHT:3PT;PADDING-BOTTOM:2PT;PADDING-LEFT:4PT;">
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;Foreign Operations
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;">
</P>
</DIV>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
	market our products to customers outside of Canada through both direct and indirect distribution channels, and through our channel partnership with Nokia. We also carry out R&amp;D
	activities in Shanghai, China. See "Part&nbsp;I&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;Item&nbsp;4.&nbsp;Information on the Company&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;B.&nbsp;Description
	of the Business&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;General&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;Markets", "&#150;&nbsp;Distribution Methods" and
	"&#150;&nbsp;Research and Development Activities" above, and "Part&nbsp;I&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;Item&nbsp;3.&nbsp;Key
	Information&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;D.&nbsp;Risk&nbsp;Factors".
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Bankruptcy and Similar Procedures
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have never been subject to a bankruptcy, receivership or similar procedure and no such procedures are proposed for the current
	fiscal&nbsp;year.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<!-- BOXING PARAGRAPH(S) -->
</FONT>
</P>
<DIV STYLE="WIDTH:100%;BORDER:SOLID #000000 1PT;MARGIN-RIGHT:1PT;PADDING-TOP:1PT;PADDING-RIGHT:3PT;PADDING-BOTTOM:2PT;PADDING-LEFT:4PT;">
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;Lending
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;">
</P>
</DIV>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
	have established a long term credit facility with Comerica Bank and Export Development Canada. As at February&nbsp;28, 2015, this asset based credit facility was for a total of
	$40.0&nbsp;million plus $4.0&nbsp;million for letters of credit and foreign exchange facilities. Credit availability is subject to ongoing compliance with borrowing covenants and short term assets
	on hand. As at February&nbsp;28, 2015, we had drawn $32.4&nbsp;million on the facility and $1.9&nbsp;million against our letter of credit facility. As at the date of this Annual Report, the
	drawn portion on the facility was increased to $33.7&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
	credit facility was extended on January&nbsp;6, 2014, matures on June&nbsp;1, 2016 and is secured by a first priority charge on all of our assets and the assets of our principal
	direct and indirect subsidiaries. The credit facility includes other customary terms, conditions, covenants, and representations and warranties. Borrowing options under the credit facility include
	U.S.&nbsp;dollar, Canadian dollar, and Euro loans. Interest rates vary with market rate fluctuations, with loans bearing interest in the range of 3% to 4% above the applicable base&nbsp;rates.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
	were in breach of one of our covenants in both March&nbsp;2014 and April&nbsp;2014. We obtained a waiver for these breaches and amended the terms of the facility on May&nbsp;13,
	2014. As of the date of this Annual Report, and as of February&nbsp;28, 2015, we are in compliance with all&nbsp;covenants.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	40
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A NAME="A2224732Z20-F_HTM_DM49901_C__CORPORATE_STRUCTURE">
</A>
<A NAME="A2224732Z20-F_HTM_TOC_DM49901_1">
</A>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	C.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Corporate Structure
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The intercorporate relationships between DragonWave and its material subsidiaries are set out in the chart below. As noted below,
	DragonWave has a 50.1% equity interest in DragonWave HFCL India Private Limited. DragonWave does not control the board of DragonWave HFCL India Private Limited.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2015/05/27/0001047469-15-005038_G930354.JPG" ALT="GRAPHIC" WIDTH="630" HEIGHT="636">
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A NAME="A2224732Z20-F_HTM_DM49901_D__PROPERTY,_PLANTS_AND_EQUIPMENT_">
</A>
<A NAME="A2224732Z20-F_HTM_TOC_DM49901_2">
</A>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	D.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Property, plants and equipment.
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our corporate headquarters are located in Ottawa, Ontario where we lease and occupy 33,286&nbsp;square&nbsp;feet of space. The
	lease for our office expires in November&nbsp;2016. Our headquarters do not include product manufacturing facilities. The aggregate monthly rental payment for our corporate headquarters, together
	with the maintenance fees, is approximately $61,554.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
	also lease and occupy 20,734&nbsp;square&nbsp;feet of space in another office in Ottawa, Ontario, mainly as a warehousing and testing facility. The lease for this space expires in
	November&nbsp;2016 and the aggregate monthly rental payment is $34,789, including maintenance&nbsp;fees.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	41
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=43,EFW="2224732",CP="DRAGONWAVE INC.",DN="1",CHK=203689,FOLIO='41',FILE='DISK105:[15ZBE1.15ZBE49901]DM49901A.;13',USER='SSTALKE',CD='26-MAY-2015;20:12' -->
<A NAME="A2224732Z20-F_HTM_PAGE_DM49901_1_42">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
	Shanghai, China, we lease and occupy 14,272&nbsp;square&nbsp;feet of space for research and development activities. The lease expires in September&nbsp;2017 and the aggregate
	monthly rental payment is $21,227, including maintenance&nbsp;fees.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
	also lease space in other regions to support the sales and marketing activities of our branches and subsidiaries in those&nbsp;regions.
</FONT>
</P>
</EFX_COMPANY_INFORMATION>
<EFX_UNRESOLVED_STAFF_COMMENTS>

<EFX_OPERATING_AND_FINANCIAL_REVIEW>
<A NAME="FIS_OPERATING_AND_FINANCIAL_REVIEW"></A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A NAME="A2224732Z20-F_HTM_DM49901_ITEM_5__OPERATING_AND___DM402012">
</A>
<A NAME="A2224732Z20-F_HTM_TOC_DM49901_4">
</A>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	ITEM&nbsp;5.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating and&nbsp;Financial Review and Prospects.
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A NAME="A2224732Z20-F_HTM_DM49901_A__OPERATING_RESULTS">
</A>
<A NAME="A2224732Z20-F_HTM_TOC_DM49901_5">
</A>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	A.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating results
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;DragonWave is a leading provider of high-capacity packet microwave solutions that drive next-generation IP networks. DragonWave's
	carrier-grade point-to-point packet microwave systems transmit broadband voice, video and data, enabling service providers, government agencies, enterprises and other organizations to meet their
	increasing bandwidth requirements rapidly and affordably. The principal application of DragonWave's products is mobile network backhaul. Additional applications include leased line replacement, last
	mile fiber extension and enterprise networks.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Historically,
	our financial results have fluctuated on a quarterly basis and we expect that quarterly financial results will continue to fluctuate in the future. The results of
	operations for interim periods should not be relied upon as an indication of the results to be expected or achieved in any future period or any fiscal year as a whole. Fluctuations in results reflect
	the project nature of network installations, including for end-customers we supply through Nokia. In addition, results may vary as a result of the timing of staffing, infrastructure additions required
	to support growth, and material costs required to support design initiatives.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
	fiscal year 2015, neither inflation nor deflation had a material impact on our operations. However, in light of the uncertain global economic outlook we cannot provide any
	assurance that there will be no significant variations on our operations, or the business operations of our customers and suppliers in the future which may have a material impact on our results
	of&nbsp;operations.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
	further analysis on our results of operations, see management's discussion and analysis of the Company's consolidated results of operations and financial condition for the three and
	twelve months ended February&nbsp;28, 2015 incorporated by reference into this Annual Report as Exhibit&nbsp;15.1, and the Company's consolidated results of operations and financial condition for
	the three and twelve months ended February&nbsp;28, 2014 incorporated by reference into this Annual Report as Exhibit&nbsp;15.2.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A NAME="A2224732Z20-F_HTM_DM49901_B__LIQUIDITY_AND_CAPITAL_RESOURCES">
</A>
<A NAME="A2224732Z20-F_HTM_TOC_DM49901_6">
</A>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	B.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Liquidity and capital resources
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Since our initial public offering in April&nbsp;2007 (our&nbsp;"IPO"), we have financed our operations primarily through the
	proceeds of our IPO and other follow-on public offerings, debt arrangements and cash flow from our&nbsp;operations.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
	IPO raised net proceeds of CAD$26.9million. This was followed by four further public offerings: (1)&nbsp;an offering in September&nbsp;2007 which raised net proceeds of
	CAD$22.1&nbsp;million, (2)&nbsp;our NASDAQ initial public offering in October&nbsp;2009 which raised net proceeds of CAD$70.5&nbsp;million, (3)&nbsp;an offering in September&nbsp;2013 an
	offering which raised net proceeds of $22.4&nbsp;million, and (4)&nbsp;an offering in August&nbsp;2014 which raised net proceeds of $24.0&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
	have established a long term credit facility with Comerica Bank and Export Development Canada. As at February&nbsp;28, 2015, this asset based credit facility was for a total of
	$40.0&nbsp;million plus $4.0&nbsp;million for letters of credit and foreign exchange facilities. Credit availability is subject to ongoing compliance with borrowing covenants and short term assets
	on hand. As at February&nbsp;28, 2015 we had drawn $32.4&nbsp;million on the facility and $1.9&nbsp;million against our letter of credit facility. As at the date of this Annual Report, the drawn
	portion on the facility has increased to $33.7&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	42
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=44,EFW="2224732",CP="DRAGONWAVE INC.",DN="1",CHK=980263,FOLIO='42',FILE='DISK105:[15ZBE1.15ZBE49901]DM49901A.;13',USER='SSTALKE',CD='26-MAY-2015;20:12' -->
<A NAME="A2224732Z20-F_HTM_PAGE_DM49901_1_43">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
	credit facility was extended on January&nbsp;6, 2014, matures on June&nbsp;1, 2016 and is secured by a first priority charge on all of our assets and the assets of our principal
	direct and indirect subsidiaries. The credit facility includes other customary terms, conditions, covenants, and representations and warranties. Borrowing options under the credit facility include
	U.S.&nbsp;dollar, Canadian dollar, and Euro loans. Interest rates vary with market rate fluctuations, with loans bearing interest in the range of 3% to 4% above the applicable base&nbsp;rates.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
	were in breach of one of our covenants in both March&nbsp;2014 and April&nbsp;2014. We obtained a waiver for these breaches and amended the terms of the facility on May&nbsp;13,
	2014. As of the date of this Annual Report, and as of February&nbsp;28, 2015, we are in compliance with all&nbsp;covenants.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
	of February&nbsp;28, 2015, we had approximately $23.7&nbsp;million in cash and cash equivalents which is defined as all highly liquid investments held with an original maturity of
	three months or&nbsp;less.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
	cash used in operating activities was $31.6 and $23.9&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;28, 2015 and&nbsp;2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
	further analysis on Liquidity and Capital Resources, see the management's discussion and analysis of the Company's consolidated results of operations and financial condition for the
	three and twelve months ended February&nbsp;28, 2015 incorporated by reference into this Annual Report as Exhibit&nbsp;15.1, and the Company's consolidated results of operations and financial
	condition for the three and twelve months ended February&nbsp;28, 2014 incorporated by reference into this Annual Report as Exhibit&nbsp;15.2.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A NAME="A2224732Z20-F_HTM_DM49901_C__RESEARCH_AND_DEVELOPMENT">
</A>
<A NAME="A2224732Z20-F_HTM_TOC_DM49901_7">
</A>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	C.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Research and Development
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our ability to develop technologically superior and cost-effective solutions relative to our competitors can only be achieved through
	our continued research and development ("R&amp;D") efforts.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
	R&amp;D activities take place at our headquarters in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada and in Shanghai, China. We currently have approximately 127&nbsp;personnel in our engineering group,
	representing approximately 47% of our total personnel. The majority of our engineering staff hold degrees in engineering. A large number of our senior engineering personnel have worked together for
	several years and have been responsible for the development of our products. Our R&amp;D team works closely with our diverse customer base, and incorporates feedback from our direct and indirect sales
	teams into our product development plans to improve our products and address emerging market requirements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
	November&nbsp;30, 2012, we added 100&nbsp;employees in Shanghai. As of the date of this Annual Report, there are 81&nbsp;employees in Shanghai, 74 of which are in R&amp;D. From
	June&nbsp;1, 2012 until November&nbsp;30, 2012, the services of these employees were provided under a services arrangement with&nbsp;Nokia.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Between
	June&nbsp;1, 2012 and April&nbsp;9, 2013, we also received R&amp;D services outside of China provided by Nokia under a services arrangement. These services were discontinued on
	April&nbsp;9, 2013 as part of the Renewed Framework.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
	R&amp;D expenses have historically been, and will continue to be, a significant portion of our overall cost structure as we will continue to invest in new product features and new
	platforms to better serve the current and future needs of our customers. We invested 11% and 22% of our revenues in R&amp;D during fiscal year 2015 and fiscal year 2014, respectively.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
	further analysis on Research and Development, see the management's discussion and analysis of the Company's consolidated results of operations and financial condition for the three
	and twelve months ended February&nbsp;28, 2015 incorporated by reference into this Annual Report as Exhibit&nbsp;15.1.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	43
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>

<B>
	E.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Off-balance sheet arrangements.
<BR>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
	leases listed above are arranged at market pricing levels in all jurisdictions and the lease periods listed above represent a commitment for the time period indicated. We are
	actively seeking sub-lease arrangements in a number of locations as part of our efforts to reduce costs. There can be no assurance that we will secure sub-leases or that sub-lease terms will
	be&nbsp;favorable.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
	January&nbsp;21, 2014, we subleased a portion of our Kanata office space and as such during the year ended February&nbsp;28, 2014 we recorded net rent expense of
	$84&nbsp;thousand, representing the present value of our estimated remaining rent expense for the duration of the lease after taking into account estimated future sublease income and deferred rent
	on the&nbsp;facility.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
	use an outsourced manufacturing model in which most of the component acquisition and assembly of our products is executed by third parties. Generally, we provide the supplier with a
	purchase order 90&nbsp;days in advance of expected delivery. We are responsible for the financial impact of any changes to the product requirements within this period. In some cases when a product
	has been purchased by a contract manufacturer but not pulled on for a build after a certain amount of time, we provide a deposit against that inventory, but do not take ownership of&nbsp;it.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
	contract manufacturers currently have inventory intended for use in the production of our products, and we have purchase orders in place for raw materials and manufactured products
	with these contract manufacturers as well. All of this material is considered to be part of the normal production process and we take provisions against any portion of that inventory that we do not
	expect to be fully used based on current forecasts and projections. As mentioned previously, we would generally be responsible for the cost of the material approved to be purchased on our behalf by
	our contract manufacturers should those forecasts or projections change.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
	at February&nbsp;28, 2015, we have provisions totaling $0.1&nbsp;million on inventory held by contract manufacturers that we do not expect to be fully&nbsp;used.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	44
</FONT>
</P>

	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our directors, as at the date of this Annual Report, are Peter Allen, Claude Haw, Lori O'Neill and Cesar Cesaratto. Each of our directors holds
	office until the next annual meeting of shareholders or until his successor is duly elected or appointed, unless his office becomes vacant by resignation, death, removal or other&nbsp;cause.
</FONT>

</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
	Chief Financial Officer, Russell Frederick, has been nominated for election to our board at the annual general meeting of shareholders of the Company scheduled to be held on
	June&nbsp;17, 2015 (the&nbsp;"Meeting"). If elected at the Meeting, Mr.&nbsp;Frederick will become a director effective June&nbsp;17, 2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
	directors and executive officers, as a group, beneficially own, or control or direct, directly or indirectly, a total of 1,030,837&nbsp;common shares, representing 1.37% of the
	total outstanding common shares as of the date of this Annual&nbsp;Report.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
	at the date of this Annual Report, our board of directors has three standing committees: the Audit Committee, the Compensation Committee and the Nominating and Governance Committee.
	Detailed information regarding the mandate and procedures of the Audit Committee can be found below under "Part&nbsp;I&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;Item&nbsp;6.&nbsp;Directors, Senior
	Management and Employees&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;C.&nbsp;Board Practices&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;Audit Committee", as required by National
	Instrument&nbsp;52-110&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Audit Committees
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	promulgated under applicable securities legislation.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
	have established a Strategy Committee. Prior to the resignation of Mr.&nbsp;Pons effective April&nbsp;14, 2015, the Strategy Committee was comprised of Claude Haw (Chair), Cesar
	Cesaratto and Robert Pons.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
	have also established a Disclosure Committee composed of members of management, namely Peter Allen and Russell Frederick.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
	principal occupations of our directors and executive officers as at February&nbsp;28, 2015, for at least the five preceding years are as&nbsp;follows:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Directors
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cesar Cesaratto:
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Mr.&nbsp;Cesaratto has more than 40&nbsp;years of experience in the technology industry. Mr.&nbsp;Cesaratto
	joined Nortel
	Networks Corporation, a communications equipment manufacturing company, in 1970 and assumed increasingly senior management roles during his 31&nbsp;year career with Nortel, culminating in the role
	of President, Wireless Solutions for Europe, Middle East and Africa. Mr.&nbsp;Cesaratto retired from Nortel in 2001 and has continued to be active in the technology sector. He is currently a member
	of an angel investment group dedicated to the development of technology start-up companies in the Ottawa area. He was a director of Tundra Semiconductor (2007 to 2009) and Breconridge Manufacturing
	Solutions (2007 to 2010) and is currently chairman of the board of directors of Applied Micro Circuits Corporation and serves on the board of two private start-up companies. Mr.&nbsp;Cesaratto holds
	a Bachelor of Engineering in Electrical Engineering from McGill University.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	46
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=48,EFW="2224732",CP="DRAGONWAVE INC.",DN="1",CHK=662108,FOLIO='46',FILE='DISK105:[15ZBE1.15ZBE49901]DM49901A.;13',USER='SSTALKE',CD='26-MAY-2015;20:12' -->
<A NAME="A2224732Z20-F_HTM_PAGE_DM49901_1_47">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Claude Haw, Director:
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Claude Haw is President of Venture Coaches, a private consulting and investment company, which he founded
	in 2000. From 2009 to
	2011 he was President and Chief Executive Officer of the Ottawa Centre for Regional Innovation (OCRI), Ottawa's leading economic development organization. From 2003 to early 2007, Mr.&nbsp;Haw was
	also a general partner at Skypoint Capital Corporation, an Ottawa based venture capital firm. Prior to Venture Coaches, Mr.&nbsp;Haw held a number of executive positions at Newbridge Networks
	Corporation ("Newbridge"), including Vice President of Corporate Business Development. In this role, he managed strategic investment programs in more than 20&nbsp;companies. Mr.&nbsp;Haw has also
	held senior management positions at Mitel Networks Corporation and Leigh Instruments&nbsp;Ltd. Mr.&nbsp;Haw holds a Bachelor
	of Electrical Engineering degree from Lakehead University in Thunder Bay, Ontario, Canada and has completed the Canadian Securities Course. He has completed the ICD Director Education Program and
	attained the ICD.D designation in 2012. Mr.&nbsp;Haw was also recognized for his contribution to Canadian innovation with the Queen Elizabeth II Diamond Jubilee Medal in&nbsp;2012.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Lori O'Neill, Director:
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Lori O'Neill is a Chartered Professional Accountant and Certified Public Accountant (Illinois) and
	currently provides
	consulting services to growth companies. She retired from partnership in global professional services firm in 2012 after over 24&nbsp;years serving growth companies from startups to multinationals,
	supporting complex transactions, private and public equity offerings, mergers and acquisitions in Canada and the U.S.&nbsp;Ms.&nbsp;O'Neill serves as board member and chair of the Audit and Risk
	Management Committee of the Ontario Lottery and Gaming Corporation, board member and chair of the Audit Committee of Defence Construction Canada, member of the board of directors of Hydro Ottawa, the
	University of Ottawa Heart Institute, Startup Canada, Face-2-Face, the board of governors of Ashbury College, the finance committee of the Stem Cell Network and an advisory board for the Dean of the
	Sprott School of Business. Ms.&nbsp;O'Neill graduated from Carleton University with a Bachelor of Commerce Highest Honours in 1988, achieved her CA designation in 1990, her CPA designation in 2003,
	was recognized as "Top Forty under Forty" in 1999 by the Ottawa Business Journal, and completed the ICD Director Education Program attaining the ICD.D designation in&nbsp;2012.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Robert Pons, Former Director:
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Mr.&nbsp;Pons has more than 30&nbsp;years of experience in the global telecommunications industry
	in both services
	and technology. He is currently the Executive Chairman of HC2&nbsp;Holdings&nbsp;Inc. (formerly PTGi Holdings, formerly Primus Telecommunications), a wholesale international long distance carrier.
	He is also the Vice-Chairman of MRV Communications&nbsp;Inc., and serves on the board of Concurrent Computer Corp. a global leader in multi-screen video delivery, media data management and
	monetization. From February&nbsp;2011 to April&nbsp;2014, he served as Chairman of Live Micro Systems,&nbsp;Inc. (formerly Livewire Mobile), which was a comprehensive one-stop digital content
	solution for mobile carriers. From January&nbsp;2008 until February&nbsp;2011, Mr.&nbsp;Pons was Senior Vice President of TMNG Global, a leading provider of professional services to the
	converging communications media and entertainment industries and the capital formation firms that support it. From January&nbsp;2004 until April&nbsp;2007, Mr.&nbsp;Pons served as President and
	Chief Executive Officer of Uphonia,&nbsp;Inc. (previously SmartServ Online,&nbsp;Inc.), a wireless applications service provider. From August&nbsp;2003 until January&nbsp;2004, Mr.&nbsp;Pons
	served as Interim Chief Executive Officer of SmartServ Online,&nbsp;Inc. on a consulting basis. From March&nbsp;1999 to August&nbsp;2003, he was President of FreedomPay,&nbsp;Inc., wireless
	device payment processing company. During the period January&nbsp;1994 to March&nbsp;1999, Mr.&nbsp;Pons was President of Lifesafety Solutions,&nbsp;Inc., an enterprise software company.
	Mr.&nbsp;Pons has over 30&nbsp;years of management experience with telecommunications companies including MCI,&nbsp;Inc., Sprint,&nbsp;Inc. and Geotek,&nbsp;Inc. Mr.&nbsp;Pons received a
	bachelor of arts degree with honors from Rowan University. As a pioneer in the telecommunications industry, Mr.&nbsp;Pons brought to the board of directors his experience as a senior level executive
	working in the telecommunications industry. Mr.&nbsp;Pons resigned as a director effective April&nbsp;14,&nbsp;2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Peter Allen
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	is also a director and his biographical information is set out&nbsp;below.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Executive Officers
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Peter Allen, President and Chief Executive Officer:
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Prior to joining DragonWave in 2004, Peter Allen was President and CEO of
	Innovance&nbsp;Inc.
	("Innovance"), a private reconfigurable optical networking company. Prior to 2000, Peter was the Vice President of Business Development for the Optical Networks Division of Nortel Networks Limited
	("Nortel"), holding leadership responsibility for Nortel's optical components business as well as business development responsibility for system activities. At Nortel, Peter led a 5,000-employee
	global operation spanning R&amp;D, manufacturing and sales and marketing. Peter has also held managerial positions at Ford Motor Company and Rothmans International&nbsp;plc, and has lived and worked in
	North America, Europe and&nbsp;Africa.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	47
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=49,EFW="2224732",CP="DRAGONWAVE INC.",DN="1",CHK=588509,FOLIO='47',FILE='DISK105:[15ZBE1.15ZBE49901]DM49901A.;13',USER='SSTALKE',CD='26-MAY-2015;20:12' -->
<A NAME="A2224732Z20-F_HTM_PAGE_DM49901_1_48">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Russell Frederick, Vice President, Finance and Chief Financial Officer:
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Prior to joining DragonWave in 2004, Russell Frederick
	was the Chief
	Operating Officer and Chief Financial Officer of Wavesat Wireless&nbsp;Inc. ("Wavesat"), between 2000 and 2003. Prior to Wavesat, Russell was the Chief Financial Officer of PRIOR Data
	Sciences&nbsp;Ltd. ("PRIOR"), from 1994 to 2000, where he played a key role in the management buy-out and subsequent sale of the company. Prior to his time with PRIOR, Russell was employed with
	Digital Equipment&nbsp;Ltd. of Canada in various financial roles. Russell holds a Masters of Business Administration degree in finance, as well as a Bachelor of Science degree from McMaster
	University in Hamilton, Ontario, Canada.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Erik Boch, Founder, Vice President, Engineering and Chief Technology Officer:
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Prior to co-founding DragonWave in
	February&nbsp;2000, Erik Boch held
	senior engineering or technical management positions at a number of communications and aerospace companies, namely Litton Systems Canada&nbsp;Ltd., ComDev International&nbsp;Ltd., Lockheed Martin
	Corporation and Newbridge (since acquired by Alcatel Canada,&nbsp;Inc.). While at Newbridge, Erik was Assistant Vice President of the Wireless Systems Group. Erik has been involved in various
	aspects of microwave and millimetre wave subsystem and system design for more than 22&nbsp;years. Erik led the R&amp;D team at Newbridge that introduced the first ATM-based fixed wireless access system
	in our industry. Erik has been published extensively in major networking publications, including Telephony, Microwave Journal, Wireless Review, Internet Telephony and America's Network. Erik holds
	several approved radio frequency ("RF") design patents and numerous patents pending. He is on the Technical Advisory Board of PMC-Sierra,&nbsp;Inc. (NASDAQ: PMCS), a company that designs, develops,
	markets and support semiconductor
	solutions. Erik holds a Bachelor and a Master's degree in Electrical Engineering from Carleton University, Ottawa, Ontario, Canada and is a registered professional engineer.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Barry Dahan, Executive Vice President, Global Sales:
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Barry Dahan has 30&nbsp;years' experience in the International Telecom
	industry in various
	roles. Prior to joining DragonWave in 2011, Barry was tasked with building the business and infrastructure for Starent Networks. Barry was employed with ALU and Nortel in various Executive /
	Leadership roles. Since 2010, Barry has been investing in private growth companies. Barry holds a Business Degree in Finance as well as a bachelor in engineering from Polytechnique in&nbsp;Canada.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;David Farrar, Founder&nbsp;&amp; Vice President, Operations:
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Prior to co-founding DragonWave in February&nbsp;2000, David Farrar
	was employed by
	Newbridge, where he held senior management positions in product management, R&amp;D, operations, and information technology. Prior to joining Newbridge, David was Director of Engineering at Synapse
	Corporation, a private data communications design company, and an Engineering Manager at Mitel. David holds a Bachelor of Science in Electrical Engineering from the University of Waterloo in Waterloo,
	Ontario, Canada.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Greg Friesen, Vice President, Product Management:
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Prior to joining DragonWave in 2004, Greg Friesen held senior product
	management, business
	development, network design and planning roles, at a number of communications firms, including Innovance (2000-2004), Nortel (1997-2000), and Fundy Telecom (1996). As Senior Product Manager at
	Innovance he was responsible for all product definition, architecture, and network design. He has been involved in the planning and engineering of over 10&nbsp;nationwide network deployments. Greg
	has authored numerous papers and magazine articles in publications including Microwave Journal, Telecommunications, Xchange, Telephony Online, Last Mile, AGL, Radio World, and has spoken at numerous
	industry conferences such as WiMax World, CTIA, Telecom Next, ISPCon and UTC. Greg holds two granted patents in the networking area. Greg holds a Bachelor of Science in Electrical Engineering from the
	University of Saskatchewan in Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, Canada.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Tom McLellan, Vice President, Services:
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Tom McLellan joined DragonWave in February&nbsp;2010, to lead the Services and Customer
	Support Team. Prior
	to joining DragonWave, Tom spent close to 30&nbsp;years with Nortel, in a diverse number of roles. He ran the Global Product Support team for several years, an organization of 1200&nbsp;people
	worldwide supporting all aspects of Nortel's product portfolio, Optical, Wireless and Carrier Wireline to Enterprise IP. During his tenure at Nortel he also held roles at Bell Northern Research as
	Director of its Carrier Platform business, as well as Project Management and Verification roles, managing teams in a wide number of locations, including Raleigh, North Carolina, Dallas, Texas and
	Santa Clara, California in the U.S., Istanbul, Maidenhead in the United&nbsp;Kingdom and Beijing, China. Tom has a C&amp;G of London Institute Diploma in Telecommunications and graduated with a BSc in
	Electrical and Electronic Engineering from Glasgow, Scotland.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	48
</FONT>

<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=1>
	(1)
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=1>
	All
	compensation, with the exception of Mr.&nbsp;Pons and Mr.&nbsp;Cossart, was paid in CAD&nbsp;dollars.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=1>
	(2)
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=1>
	Option
	based award values are calculated at their market value established using the Black-Scholes methodology, which has been chosen as the method to value
	options as it is the most widely recognized methodology and is accepted as a US generally accepted accounting standard. The Black-Scholes methodology considers various factors including historical
	share prices, price volatility and interest&nbsp;rates.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=1>
	(3)
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=1>
	Represents
	the value of restricted share units ("RSUs") based on the fair market value of the common shares on the date of grant of CAD$2.15 per common
	share, and an exchange rate of CAD to USD of&nbsp;0.9314.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=1>
	(4)
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=1>
	Mr.&nbsp;Pons
	was a director until his resignation effective April&nbsp;14, 2015 and he will not stand for re-election at the Meeting. His RSUs were
	terminated effective April&nbsp;14, 2015 in connection with his resignation.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=1>
	(5)
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=1>
	Mr.&nbsp;Pons's
	and Mr.&nbsp;Cossart's compensation was paid in US dollars.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=1>
	(6)
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=1>
	Mr.&nbsp;Cossart
	was a director until June&nbsp;20, 2014 as he did not stand for re-election at the annual general and special meeting of shareholders
	held on June&nbsp;20,&nbsp;2014.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	49
</FONT>
</P>

<!-- END OF USER-SPECIFIED TAGGED TABLE -->
</DIV>
</EFX_COMPENSATION_TABLE>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=1>
	(1)
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=1>
	Option
	based award values are calculated at their fair market value established using the Black-Scholes methodology, which has been chosen as the method to
	value options as it is the most widely recognized methodology and is accepted as a US generally accepted accounting standard. The Black-Scholes methodology considers various factors including
	historical share prices, price volatility and interest&nbsp;rates.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=1>
	(2)
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=1>
	Foreign
	currency is translated at the average rate for the 2015 fiscal year. CAD to USD is 0.8929 (1.1199).
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=1>
	(3)
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=1>
	Non-equity
	incentive plan compensation consists of sales commission.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=1>
	(4)
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=1>
	Non-equity
	incentive plan compensation consists of a one-time bonus associated with acquisition of the Nokia Siemens Networks microwave transport business.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=1>
	(5)
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=1>
	All
	compensation, with the exception of Mr.&nbsp;Dahan, is paid in CAD dollars. All compensation is translated at the average rate for the 2015 fiscal
	year, 2014 fiscal year and the 2013 fiscal year. The rates used were CAD to USD, 0.8929 (1.1199), CAD to USD, 0.9579 (1.0439), and CAD to USD, 1.0039 (0.9961), respectively.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=1>
	(6)
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=1>
	Mr.&nbsp;Dahan's
	compensation is paid in GBP. His compensation is translated at the average rate for the 2015 fiscal year, 2014 fiscal year and the 2013
	fiscal year. The rates used were GBP to USD, 1.6319 (0.6128), GBP to USD, 1.5690 (0.6370), and GBP to USD, 1.5929 (0.6278), respectively.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=1>
<A NAME="A2224732Z20-F_HTM_DO49901_C__BOARD_PRACTICES_">
</A>
<A NAME="A2224732Z20-F_HTM_TOC_DO49901_2">
</A>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	C.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Board Practices.
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company and its board of directors are committed to exercising effective corporate governance in the conduct of the Company's
	business and the board's affairs. National Instrument&nbsp;58-101&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Disclosure of Corporate Governance Practices
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	(the&nbsp;"National Instrument") promulgated by the applicable Canadian securities regulatory authorities requires reporting issuers to disclose their approach to corporate governance and relate
	their corporate governance practices to specific guidelines. The National Instrument serves as the reference point for this Statement of Corporate Governance Practices.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Overview
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our board is responsible for managing the business and affairs of the Company. It is the board of director's belief that good corporate
	governance improves corporate performance and benefits all shareholders.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	50
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=52,EFW="2224732",CP="DRAGONWAVE INC.",DN="1",CHK=814500,FOLIO='50',FILE='DISK105:[15ZBE1.15ZBE49901]DO49901A.;9',USER='RRICKEN',CD='27-MAY-2015;11:35' -->
<A NAME="A2224732Z20-F_HTM_PAGE_DO49901_1_51">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Board of Directors
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The board of directors is currently comprised of four directors. Directors of the Company are elected annually by the shareholders. The
	composition of the board, assuming the election of the director nominees of management, provides a mix of skills and experience to guide the strategy and operations of the Company, which the board
	considers important considering the increasingly global nature of the Company's stakeholders.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
	board has concluded that three of the four current directors (namely Cesar Cesaratto, Claude Haw and Lori O'Neill) are "independent" within the meaning of the National Instrument and
	NASDAQ rules. The definitions of "independence" in the National Instrument and NASDAQ rules generally focus on whether a
	director, directly or indirectly, has a material relationship with an issuer that could reasonably be expected to interfere with the exercise of that director's independent judgment, provided that
	employees and certain other categories of individuals are considered to have material relationships with an&nbsp;issuer.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
	board determines, on an annual basis, whether board members are "independent" within the meaning of the National Instrument and NASDAQ rules. On May&nbsp;12, 2015, the board
	undertook its annual determination of the independence status of each of the directors in relation to the solicitation of proxies for the Meeting. If all of management's nominees are elected at the
	Meeting, three of the five directors (namely Cesar Cesaratto, Claude Haw and Lori O'Neill) will be "independent" within the meaning of the National Instrument and NASDAQ rules. Peter Allen and Russell
	Frederick are not "independent" as a result of being executive officers of the Company. The board believes that the extensive knowledge of the Company's business and industry brought to the Company by
	Mr.&nbsp;Allen and Mr.&nbsp;Frederick are beneficial to the other directors and contributes to the effectiveness of the&nbsp;board.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
	following is a list of those management nominees for election as directors of the Company who are also directors of other reporting issuers:
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_NAME_AND_TITLE>
<A NAME="FIS_NAME_AND_TITLE"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;WIDTH:75%;MARGIN-LEFT:12%;">
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
</FONT>
</P>

</EFX_NAME_AND_TITLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At each board meeting, the "independent" directors have the ability to hold
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	in&nbsp;camera
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	sessions without the presence of the non-independent directors and other members of the Company's management, a process intended to facilitate open and candid discussion among the "independent"
	directors. Although not regularly scheduled, the board exercises its ability to hold such
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	in&nbsp;camera
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	sessions whenever any "independent" director
	deems it necessary. For the period of March&nbsp;1, 2014 through February&nbsp;28, 2015 the board met in person on five occasions and conducted two formal
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	in&nbsp;camera
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	sessions.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Claude
	Haw, an "independent" director, serves as the board's Chair. In addition to chairing all board meetings, the Chair's role is to facilitate and chair discussions among the
	Company's "independent" directors, facilitate communication between the "independent" directors and the Company's management, and, if and when necessary, act as a spokesperson on behalf of the board
	in dealing with the press and members of the public. The Chair's responsibilities and duties are described in detail in a position description developed by the board in co-operation with the current
	Chair. The existence of the position of Chair is not intended in any way to inhibit discussions among the directors or between any of them and the Company's management. The Chair, the Nominating and
	Governance Committee, the Audit Committee, the Compensation Committee, the Disclosure Committee and the board at large are responsible for ensuring that the board effectively discharges
	its&nbsp;mandate.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Majority Voting for Directors
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The board believes that each of its members should have the confidence and support of the Company's shareholders. On May&nbsp;2,
	2012, as recommended by the Nominating and Governance Committee, the board adopted a majority voting policy for the election of directors at the Meeting. This policy provides that in an uncontested
	election, any nominee for director who receives more "withheld" votes than "for" votes will tender his or her resignation to the board, effective on acceptance by the board. The board will refer the
	resignation to the Nominating and Governance Committee for consideration. The board will promptly accept the resignation
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	51
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=53,EFW="2224732",CP="DRAGONWAVE INC.",DN="1",CHK=817325,FOLIO='51',FILE='DISK105:[15ZBE1.15ZBE49901]DO49901A.;9',USER='RRICKEN',CD='27-MAY-2015;11:35' -->
<A NAME="A2224732Z20-F_HTM_PAGE_DO49901_1_52">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	unless
	the Nominating and Governance Committee determines that there are extraordinary circumstances relating to the composition of the board or the voting results that should delay the acceptance of
	the resignation or justify rejecting it. In any event, it is expected that the resignation will be accepted (or&nbsp;in rare cases rejected) within 90&nbsp;days of the&nbsp;Meeting.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Mandate of the Board
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On February&nbsp;23, 2007, the board adopted a written mandate of directors' duties and responsibilities. A copy of the Company's
	Mandate for the board of directors is available on the Company's website at www.dragonwaveinc.com.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
	board has the authority to retain independent legal, accounting and other consultants. The board may request any officer or employee of the Company or outside counsel or the
	external/internal auditors to attend a meeting of the board or to meet with any member of, or consultant to, the&nbsp;board.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Board Committees
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The board of directors has established the Audit Committee, the Compensation Committee, the Nominating and Governance Committee, the
	Disclosure Committee and the Strategy Committee to assist the board in efficiently carrying out its responsibilities. The board does not currently have an executive committee.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Audit Committee
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The mandate, role, responsibilities and procedures of the Audit Committee are set forth in the Company's Audit Committee Charter. The
	Audit Committee is responsible for, among other things, reviewing the Company's financial reporting procedures, internal controls and the performance of the Company's external auditors. The Audit
	Committee is also responsible for reviewing quarterly financial statements, the annual financial statements and related press releases prior to their approval by the full board and certain other
	documents required by regulatory authorities. The Audit Committee Charter addresses in detail the relationship between the Audit Committee, the Company's external auditors and management of the
	Company, and contemplates direct communication channels between the Audit
	Committee and the external auditors. The Audit Committee is empowered to retain persons having special competence as necessary to assist it in fulfilling its responsibilities. Each of the Audit
	Committee members must be "independent" within the meaning of the National Instrument, NASDAQ rules and Rule&nbsp;10A-3 under the Exchange Act.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
	of the date of this Annual Report, the Audit Committee is comprised of three "independent" directors: Lori O'Neill (Committee Chair), Claude Haw and Cesar Cesaratto, each of whom is
	"independent", including within the meaning of Rule&nbsp;10A-3 of the Exchange Act. Each Audit Committee member is "financially literate" within the meaning of National
	Instrument&nbsp;52-110&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Audit Committees
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	("NI&nbsp;52-110") and each of Lori O'Neill and Claude Haw is an
	"audit committee financial expert", as defined by U.S.&nbsp;Securities and Exchange Commission rules.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Compensation Committee
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Compensation Committee makes recommendations to the board on executive compensation, including the compensation of the President
	and Chief Executive Officer. The responsibilities of the Compensation Committee also include oversight of the Company's equity compensation plans and management succession strategy. Each of the
	Compensation Committee members must be "independent" within the meaning of the National Instrument and NASDAQ&nbsp;rules.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
	Compensation Committee is currently composed of two "independent" directors: Cesar Cesaratto (Committee Chair), Claude Haw. Following the Meeting, the board will determine an
	appropriate member of the board to join the Compensation Committee.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
	members of the Compensation Committee have direct experience with matters related to compensation policies and practices. Mr.&nbsp;Haw, in particular, has been a member of the
	Compensation Committee since November&nbsp;2003, and has been directly involved with compensation matters as a member of the
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	52
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=54,EFW="2224732",CP="DRAGONWAVE INC.",DN="1",CHK=459322,FOLIO='52',FILE='DISK105:[15ZBE1.15ZBE49901]DO49901A.;9',USER='RRICKEN',CD='27-MAY-2015;11:35' -->
<A NAME="A2224732Z20-F_HTM_PAGE_DO49901_1_53">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	compensation
	committees of Meriton Networks Company from 2000 to 2008. He has also served as a member of the compensation committee for Accedian and Teradici Corporation.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
	members of the Compensation Committee have a breadth and depth of experience with both public and private companies that enables them to make decisions on the suitability of our
	compensation policies and practices. As noted above in their respective biographies, each member of the Compensation Committee has held executive positions with entities in the technology sector and
	each is well-positioned to make
	determinations with respect to the compensation policies and practices of the Company. Moreover, if the Compensation Committee determines that additional information is required in order to make a
	decision with respect to any compensation policy or practice, the Compensation Committee has the authority to engage external consultants at the expense of the&nbsp;Company.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
	Compensation Committee meets a minimum of twice every year and after each meeting reports to the board the results of its activities and any reviews undertaken. The Compensation
	Committee makes recommendations to the board as deemed appropriate.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Nominating and Governance Committee
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Pursuant to the Nominating and Governance Committee Charter, the mandate of the Nominating and Governance Committee is to assist the
	directors of the Company in carrying out the board's oversight responsibility for ensuring that the strategic direction of the Company is reviewed annually and that the board and each of its
	committees carry out their respective functions in accordance with an appropriate process. The Nominating and Governance Committee is responsible for governance issues and for identifying, recruiting,
	nominating, endorsing, recommending the appointment of, and orienting, new directors and committee members, as well as the ongoing training and education of existing directors. The Nominating and
	Governance Committee is also responsible for assessing the effectiveness of the board as a whole, each committee of the board, and the contribution of each individual director. At least every two
	years, this includes a survey of board effectiveness, which was most recently conducted and reported on to the board in May&nbsp;2015. As part of this review process, the board also discussed and
	considered the constitution of the board and the committees of the board, including board size, split between executive and non-executive members, diversity of directors and skills and experience
	relevant to the&nbsp;Company.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
	Nominating and Governance Committee is responsible for annually recommending to the board whether a director should be nominated for re-election based upon the Nominating and
	Governance Committee's consideration of his or her performance in office and any other factors deemed relevant. The Chairman of the board, the Chief Executive Officer and other individual directors
	may also identify potential candidates as directors and the Nominating and Governance Committee or the full board, as the case may be, may review such candidates and make appropriate recommendations.
	During the first quarter of fiscal 2015, the Nominating and Governance Committee reviewed and discussed the background, qualifications, industry experience, public company experience, diversity and
	existing relationship with DragonWave of several potential nominees for director of the Company. The Nominating and Governance Committee also considered diversity issues and how the skill set of each
	candidate would complement the skill set of the other directors. In May&nbsp;2015, the Nominating and Governance Committee recommended that Russell Frederick be put forward as a nominee for director
	of the Company in view of his background and qualifications, his history of serving effectively as a director of the Company, his extensive knowledge of the industry and the Company, and the
	desirability of maintaining a board consisting of at least five directors. The Nominating and Governance Committee is also actively considering further independent nominees for the&nbsp;board.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
	Nominating and Governance Committee also monitors the size and composition of the board and its committees to ensure effective decision-making and reports to the full board on any
	resulting recommendations.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
	Nominating and Governance Committee also reviews the Company's Insider Trading Policy, Disclosure Policy and Code of Business Conduct and Ethics and is responsible for recommending
	changes and any action that may be required or desired to respond to any breach of any such policy or code. On May&nbsp;2, 2012, the Nominating and Governance Committee recommended that the board
	adopt amendments to the Company's Insider Trading Policy to restrict the purchase of certain financial instruments by directors, officers and employees of the&nbsp;Company.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	53
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=55,EFW="2224732",CP="DRAGONWAVE INC.",DN="1",CHK=95998,FOLIO='53',FILE='DISK105:[15ZBE1.15ZBE49901]DO49901A.;9',USER='RRICKEN',CD='27-MAY-2015;11:35' -->
<A NAME="A2224732Z20-F_HTM_PAGE_DO49901_1_54">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Each
	of the Nominating and Governance Committee members must be "independent" within the meaning of the National Instrument and NASDAQ rules. The Nominating and Governance Committee is
	currently composed of three "independent" directors: Claude Haw (Committee Chair), Cesar Cesaratto and Lori&nbsp;O'Neill.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
	full board will continue to be directly involved in corporate governance matters upon the recommendation of the Nominating and Governance Committee and where otherwise appropriate.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A
	copy of the Company's Nominating and Governance Committee Charter is available on the Company's website at www.dragonwaveinc.com and otherwise may be obtained free of charge upon
	request from Investor Relations at the Company's head office located at 411&nbsp;Legget Drive, Suite&nbsp;600, Ottawa, Ontario, K2K&nbsp;3C9.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Strategy Committee
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The mandate of the board provides that the board is responsible for monitoring the Company's progress in achieving its goals and
	objectives and for the Company's direction in response to changing circumstances. In January&nbsp;2013, the board determined to form the Strategy Committee to assist the board as a whole in this
	function and specifically to investigate, review, consider and advise the board in relation to the Company's strategy. The mandate of the Strategy Committee provides that the committee is to be
	comprised of at least three independent directors and, prior to the resignation of Mr.&nbsp;Pons effective April&nbsp;14, 2015, the Strategy Committee was comprised of Claude Haw (Chair), Cesar
	Cesaratto and Robert Pons. Following the Meeting, the board will consider an appropriate member of the board to join the Strategy Committee. The board as a whole comprehensively reviewed the Company's
	business strategy most recently in November&nbsp;2012. This review process will continue in the context of the Strategy Committee. The Strategy Committee meets at least once each&nbsp;quarter.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Disclosure Committee
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company has adopted a written Disclosure Policy and has formed a Disclosure Committee consisting of members of senior management
	(namely, Peter Allen and Russell Frederick) in order to oversee the Company's disclosure practices and generally regulate the manner in which the Company and its directors, officers, employees and
	other representatives interact with shareholders and other stakeholders, analysts and the public. The Company's Disclosure Policy has been established in accordance with relevant disclosure
	requirements set out in applicable Canadian securities legislation. The Disclosure Committee was formed in February&nbsp;2007 and meets periodically on an as-needed basis throughout the&nbsp;year.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A
	copy of the Company's Disclosure Committee Charter and Disclosure Policy is available on the Company's website at www.dragonwaveinc.com and otherwise may be obtained free of charge
	upon request from Investor Relations at the Company's head office located at 411&nbsp;Legget Drive, Suite&nbsp;600, Ottawa, Ontario, K2K&nbsp;3C9.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	54
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
